articles.headline: Charging a Premium for Movies, at a Cost
articles.snippet: High-priced tickets and premiums for 3-D are rewarding shareholders but may be driving away moviegoers.
articles.abstract: High-priced tickets and premiums for 3-D are rewarding shareholders but may be driving away moviegoers.
articles.lead_paragraph: SANTA MONICA, Calif. — Would you go to the movies more if tickets cost less?

articles.headline: Data Centers’ Power Use Less Than Was Expected
articles.snippet: Data centers’ unquenchable thirst for power has been slaked by the recession and new technology, a report says.
articles.abstract: Data centers’ unquenchable thirst for power has been slaked by the recession and new technology, a report says.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Data centers’ unquenchable thirst for electricity has been slaked by the global recession and by a combination of new power-saving technologies, according to an independent report on data center power use from 2005 to 2010.

articles.headline: From Spending to Cuts, While the Economy Stalls
articles.snippet: The debt deal would complete an about-face in the government’s role from postrecession spending to outsize cuts in the future.
articles.abstract: The debt deal would complete an about-face in the government’s role from postrecession spending to outsize cuts in the future.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The nation’s political leaders agreed on Sunday to spend and invest less money in the American economy, a step that economists said risks the reversal of a faltering recovery, in the hope of improving the nation’s long-term prosperity.
articles.byline: By Binyamin Appelbaum and Catherine Rampell

articles.headline: Optimism on Wall St. Tempered by Hurdles
articles.snippet: Doomsday talk that had dominated recent weeks faded as political leaders signaled they had reached a compromise.
articles.abstract: Doomsday talk that had dominated recent weeks faded as political leaders signaled they had reached a compromise.
articles.lead_paragraph: After an anxious weekend spent glued to their BlackBerrys and iPhones, bankers and investors breathed a sigh of relief Sunday as lawmakers forged an agreement to raise the nation’s debt ceiling ahead of Monday’s trading.

articles.headline: Hopeful, but Wary at Money Markets
articles.snippet: While some investors have shifted assets to combat the uncertainty surrounding the debt ceiling debate, managers and regulators of money market funds say they’re optimistic.
articles.abstract: While some investors have shifted assets to combat the uncertainty surrounding the debt ceiling debate, managers and regulators of money market funds say they’re optimistic.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Money market funds, stuffed with Treasury notes and other short-term government securities, have long been considered the safest of harbors by millions of investors and institutions alike. But with the prospect of a default or a downgrade in the nation’s creditworthiness, billions of dollars have fled the funds as investors grapple with uncertainty.

articles.headline: After Protracted Fight, Both Sides Emerge Bruised
articles.snippet: A full victory lap was not expected — or, perhaps, deserved — by those on either side of the debate, which has consumed the capital, unnerved the financial markets and infuriated Americans.
articles.abstract: A full victory lap was not expected — or, perhaps, deserved — by those on either side of the debate, which has consumed the capital, unnerved the financial markets and infuriated Americans.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Obama and Congressional leaders have stitched together an agreement to prevent a national default, provided their 11th-hour deal does not fracture on Monday, but the epic budget battle has failed to resolve another question: which party can be better trusted to govern?

articles.headline: Japanese Find Radioactivity on Their Own
articles.snippet: As the government fumbles its reaction to the widespread contamination, residents are using their own dosimeters.
articles.abstract: As the government fumbles its reaction to the widespread contamination, residents are using their own dosimeters.
articles.lead_paragraph: IWAKI, Japan — Kiyoko Okoshi had a simple goal when she spent about $625 for a dosimeter: she missed her daughter and grandsons and wanted them to come home.

articles.headline: Al Jazeera English Arrives on N.Y. Cable
articles.snippet: The Qatar-based Al Jazeera has struggled to secure American outlets for its English-language TV news channel.
articles.abstract: The Qatar-based Al Jazeera has struggled to secure American outlets for its English-language TV news channel.
articles.lead_paragraph: Every cable news channel has its moment.

articles.headline: Small City, Big Debt Problems
articles.snippet: Retired employees of Central Falls, R.I., face sharp benefit cuts, but bondholders appear to be unscathed.
articles.abstract: Retired employees of Central Falls, R.I., face sharp benefit cuts, but bondholders appear to be unscathed.
articles.lead_paragraph: Even as officials in Washington pledged to cut domestic spending, the city of Central Falls, R.I., landed in bankruptcy court on Monday, a stark reminder that some American cities have debts so overwhelming that no amount of belt tightening can set things right.
articles.byline: By Mary Williams Walsh and Katie Zezima
